column26: Febrile seizure (within the age range of 3 months to 6 years)
column93: This awake and sleep EEG of a 4-year-old was performed without any prior sedation. During awake status, posterior dominant, synchronous, and symmetrical background activity at 8 Hz was observed which was of moderate to high amplitude which attenuated with opening of eyes. Photic stimulation was performed at the frequencies of 1-21 Hz.  Symmetrical photoentrainment was seen. Hyperventilation procedure produced posterior dominant generalized build-up. In stage I sleep, vertex waves were seen. In stage II sleep, sleep spindles and K complexes were noted. During slow wave sleep, diffusely distributed higher amplitude delta frequency activity was seen. During hyperventilation 5 clinical seizures ranging from 12 to 21 seconds in durations with semiology of cessation of hyperventilation, staring, looking to left, eye blinking, rubbing face/nose and mouth automatisms, with EEG showing 2.5- 3 Hz frontal dominant generalized spike and wave discharges with sometimes not clear onset and not clear offset, instead showing slowing, were recorded.  During drowse/sleep 3 additional seizures lasting from 5-16 seconds were captured. Intermittent frequent paroxysmal high amplitude poly spike and wave discharges were seen during sleep. Interpretation and Recommendation: This EEG shows clinico-electrographic correlation of absence epilepsy.
column131: Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior
column141: •	Developed behavior issues-- tantrums and lashing out for no apparent reason •	Ethosuxamide first started late 9/2019 just before age 5 years •	Ethosuxamide improved the behavior issues and there was some reduction in seizures but seizures still occuring •	12/2019 added depakote and weaned off ethosuxamide •	While on Depakote alone-- behavioral issues worsened (really bad tantrums, throwing things, eyes were glazed over but not listening); also began having suicidal thoughts (5 years old), homicidal thoughts •	1/2020 while on Depakote alone, added Vitamin B6 •	Behaviors and psychiatric symptoms began to improve after B6, but still having some seizures (improved over no therapy, but still with sz) •	2/2020 Added back ethosuxamide (on top of Depakote) •	3/2020 still having some sz + behavioral tantrums; adjusted ethosuxamide dose (increased) until 5/2020 •	6/2020 Full seizure control, improved EEG, no more behavioral/psychiatric symptoms •	Completely seizure-free since 6/2020

column16: Affected father with movement disorder, epilepsy and mild ID
column93: At onset: 8 electroclinical seizures (3 to 10 seconds) constituted by secondarily generalized discharges of spike-wave complexes 3.0-3.5 Hz frequency and up to 800 uV amplitude with greater expression at the level of both occipital areas with alternating predominance. Clinically, blinking, change of facial expression and slight hypotonia (more evident in left arm). Sleep: Moderate signs of distress-brain irritation of a focal type on both occipital areas with alternating hemispheric predominance that markedly increase their incidence and tend to spread over the rest of the areas of the convexity of the hemispheres during N1 sleep and REM sleep. Background activity normal (3 years old). patient.

column93: Six electro-clinical seizures, in which the patient presents with cephalic and upper trunk forward fall, and is associated with an onset that appears focal in posterior regions, followed by a generalized discharge of epileptiform activity, at 2.0-2.5 Hz, of variable duration up to 11 seconds. - Three generalized discharges of epileptiform activity at 2.0-2.5 Hz frequency, preceded by slow waves in posterior regions, preceded by slow waves in posterior regions, without associated clinical evaluation.- Photoparoxysmal response induced light stimulation at low frequency (3 and 5 Hz), observing generalized discharge of epileptiform activity at 3 Hz, associated with ocular retroversion, oromandibular movements and slow cephalic flexion.

column141: None definite - very jittery as a newborn; as an infant had stereotypies - these have largely settled, although still has some 'flapping'. Falls a little more than expected for age, but gait is ok (walks, runs, jumps) and no definite ataxia/other movement disorder. Dysmorphology: Has Poland syndrome on the right side. Partial sagittal synostosis (managed conservatively), duplex ureter on the right. Engaging, social. No creative/imaginary play. Some obsessive and aggressive behaviours, and repetitive play. As an infant - extremely irritable, screamed for large parts of the day for the first 10 weeks of life. MR: One nodule of heterotopia at the posterior horn of left lateral ventricle, partial sagittal synostosis, otherwise normal.Variant non-maternal. Sperm donor.

column16: Biological mother in and out of institutions, not well functioning, ID to some degree

The same variant was also identified in the father, who never had seizures, but is described as having autistic traits. •       The same variant was subsequently identified in the full brother of the proband, who has learning difficulty (special school) but again never had seizures. He also has cerebral palsy attributed to neonatal stroke. •       Lastly, the variant was found in the full sister of the proband, who has emerging concerns about educational attainment and social communication, but never had seizures
